content:
Genital herpes: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis, prevention

According to Herpes.org.nz page of the Sexually Transmitted Diseases Education Foundation (STIEF): 22% of sexually active adults are infected with genital herpes caused by HSV-2. 75% of them are infected by sexual partners who are completely unaware they have the disease. So what is genital herpes? What are the causes, symptoms, diagnosis and prevention? (first)

What is genital herpes?
Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the Herpes Simplex virus (HSV).
Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the Herpes Simplex virus (HSV). According to statistics, on average, 1 in 8 sexually active Australian adults has genital herpes. (2)
Genital herpes causes outbreaks of blisters or sores on the genitals and anus. The disease often recurs/re-infects many times throughout life, especially when resistance is reduced (anxiety, insomnia, not eating enough...)

Causes of genital herpes infection
Genital herpes is spread through skin-to-skin contact with someone who has the HSV virus, usually through genital or oral sex. The disease is also spread through kissing, foreplay or non-penetrative sex.
There are 2 types of HSV, both of which affect the lips, mouth, genitals or anus, however:
HSV-1 often causes cold sores on the lips or face; HSV-2 often causes genital herpes.
The HSV virus is most easily spread through cold sores or cold sores, but is still contagious even when the person does not have cold sores, cold sores, or other symptoms. Genital herpes is not spread through hugging, sharing swimming pools or sharing contact with toilet seats.
See more: What is Herpes? Common causes and symptoms

Recognize common genital herpes symptoms
Recognize common genital herpes symptoms
The appearance of herpes is a sign of an outbreak of genital herpes. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates that on average, the first outbreak will appear 4 days after infection with the virus. (3)
1. About the penis
For men with genital herpes, herpes will appear on the penis, scrotum, buttocks, and skin around or near the anus.
2. About the vagina
For women with genital herpes, blisters will appear in the vagina, anus, buttocks or surrounding skin areas.
3. General symptoms
General symptoms of genital herpes include:
Herpes appears in the mouth, on the lips, face, and anywhere else that comes into contact with infected skin.; The infected area often begins to itch or tingle before the blisters actually appear.; The blisters burst to form open, oozing ulcers; A scab appears at the site of the ulcer within a week of the outbreak.; Lymph glands are swollen. These lymph glands work to fight infection and inflammation in the body.; Genital herpes causes headaches, body aches and fever.

How dangerous is genital herpes?
Herpes virus tends to hide (sleep) in nerve ganglia, so it is difficult to cure completely. Genital herpes virus rarely threatens the patient's life but is extremely dangerous for pregnant women. Genital Herpes virus outbreaks during pregnancy increase the risk of premature birth, the fetus may become infected or die in the womb. (4)

Risk factors that increase the likelihood of infection?
Some risk factors increase the likelihood of genital herpes infection: (5)
Contact with genitals through oral, vaginal or anal sex without using safe measures. Women are at higher risk of getting genital herpes. The virus spreads more easily from men to women than from women to men.; Have sex with multiple partners. People with a greater number of sexual partners will have a higher incidence of genital herpes.; Have a partner who has genital herpes but does not take medication to treat it.
1. How common is genital herpes?
Genital herpes is quite common. Although genital herpes is caused by HSV-2, HSV-1 is also spread through contact, forming genital herpes; The World Health Organization (WHO)  estimated that 491.5 million people were infected with HSV-2 in 2016. This number represents more than 1/10 of the world's population between the ages of 15 – 49.; WHO also estimates that 3.7 billion people were infected with HSV-1 in the same year, accounting for about two-thirds of the world's population under 50 years of age.

When to see a doctor?
If you develop symptoms of genital herpes or realize you may have been exposed to HSV; Patients come to see a Dermatologist - Skin Aesthetics specialist to be examined, diagnosed and advised on the use of medication.

Methods of diagnosing genital herpes
Dermatologists - Skin Aesthetics diagnose genital herpes transmission by visually examining skin lesions. Although not always necessary, your doctor can confirm the diagnosis through laboratory tests (HSV PCR test).
Blood tests can diagnose HSV before an outbreak occurs. However, if there has been no exposure to the virus and no symptoms are displayed, it is not necessary to screen for HSV-1 or HSV-2.

How to treat genital herpes?
1. Medicine
Antiviral medications help speed up ulcer healing time and reduce pain. The medicine is used at the first signs of an outbreak (itching and other symptoms).; If the first flare-up has already occurred, your Dermatologist will prescribe medication to reduce the likelihood of future flare-ups.
2. Home care
People with genital herpes should bathe in warm water and use mild detergents, keep the area with herpes clean and dry, and wear loose cotton clothes to help the body feel more comfortable.

How is genital herpes transmitted?
Genital herpes is transmitted mainly through unsafe sex, including:
Penile-vaginal sex; Anal sex.; Any other activity involving contact between genitals.; Genital herpes can be contracted through oral sex. Oral herpes can spread to the genital and anal areas and vice versa.
Although HSV is usually transmitted through skin-to-skin contact, the virus is also found in the semen, saliva and vaginal secretions of infected people.

Measures to prevent infection
Measures to prevent genital herpes infection
Sexually active adults can reduce their risk of genital herpes infection by:
Use protection methods when having sex such as condoms and dental dams.; Do not have sex with someone who has herpes symptoms. However, HSV is still transmitted even when there are no symptoms.; Limit the number of sexual partners, be faithful to your partner and ask them to do the same.

Related questions
1. What should you do when you detect genital herpes infection during pregnancy?
Symptoms common to newborns infected with vaginal genital herpes include sores on the face, body, and genitals and lead to serious complications:
Blind.; Brain damage.; Dead.
If genital herpes infection is detected during pregnancy, it is necessary to discuss frankly with the treating doctor for advice and apply preventive measures to prevent the virus from being transmitted to the fetus. If the mother has herpes along the birth canal, doctors recommend a cesarean section instead of a normal vaginal birth.
2. What happens if Genital Herpes is not treated?
Genital herpes is not too dangerous for adults. In rare cases, genital herpes can cause complications, but the condition will not worsen over time.
However, the prolonged illness causes pain and makes the patient feel self-conscious. Antiviral treatments help reduce symptoms and severity of outbreaks.
Genital herpes is a common sexual disease that rarely leads to dangerous complications if treated promptly. Grasping knowledge about genital herpes helps prevent and treat the disease effectively, ensuring the health safety of yourself and those around you.
